reviews.review_title: How To Make A Bad Book Worse
reviews.content: Imagine this, a remake of 'Star Wars' which focuses entirely on two friends, Luke and Biggs going to pick up some power converters. This one scene is dragged out for two hours. That's it, that's the entire movie! No, Jedi knights, no war against the empire, no blowing up the death star. The remake is just one scene from the original dragged to two hours without any mention of the larger story which actually interested the original audiences. That's the remake of 'Left Behind.'Not of as it 'Left Behind' was anywhere on the level of 'Star Wars.'Somehow this Hollywood production has EVEN WORSE production quality than the original 2000 direct to video Kirk Cameron version.This is based on Tim LaHaye's best selling "direct from God revelations" about the end times.It's told from the point of view of GNN (Global New Network) reporter Buck Williams in Israel when the Soviet Union invades! God himself comes down to smite the Red Army and save Israel.Then the Rapture happens. Millions disappear into thin air. This of course is the heretical theory that if you believe in the Rapture enough you will be taken to heaven before the end of the world, hence avoiding the horror and headaches of the chaos.Williams later discovers that the new leader of the UN is actually the antichrist.The new Nicholas (Coppola) "Cage" film misses the ENTIRE point of the book! It focuses only on ONE single scene from the book where Buck Williams is on a panicked airplane and when the Rapture occurs. But Buck (Chad Michael Murray) isn't the star, Nicholas Cage the pilot is!There are so many other odd things about the film as well. Although people disappear, clothing appearing out of nowhere. Seriously, there's a scene in a shopping mall where clothing just drops from the ceiling. Children's clothing! Was the mall using child labor to clean the ceiling or something? Also, the character of Bruce Barnes is Caucasian in the novel but played by a black actor. He was also played by a black actor in the original because he was a member of Kirk Cameron's church. So why is he black in the remake? Did the film makers even read the book? So the movie utterly misses the point of the novel altogether. One scene from the book is expanded to take up the entire film.What about the Soviet Union invading Israel? That scene might have made a good movie. Silly sure, but exciting.The Kirk Cameron version is at least entertaining on some base levels. Or to laugh at. The actors literally took the novel as gospel so you certainly put their souls into it, literally. This remake is just so bizarre.Who was target audience? Fans of the book will be disappointed and the rest of the population loath the Rapture cult so much they'll stay away from it altogether.

I then looked at what the film was about and the penny dropped - The Rapture.Oh my god, I mean, anyone who is absurdly stupid enough to believe in God and the Rapture would love this film. Everyone else in the world who has the smallest amount of common sense will, I am sure, agree with me and just turn the film off as it is just not worth anyone's time.I have just one question... Why Cage? Why???

Just my opinion, of course, but I found it to be pretty bad. There are some bright spots, primarily Nicholas Cage and Chad Michael Murray, but for the most part, the dialogue feels hackneyed and forced, the soundtrack is just awful. I mean, Christian pop? Really? We can't do orchestral music to heighten tension? It's just full of smarm, and sanctimoniousness. The few breakout moments were decent, and I'm glad they gave the female actors in this movie more to do than panic or worry about their men, but it was produced by Paul Lalonde, so no matter how appetizing the rest of the sandwich, there's a big turd slapped on it right there. The Cloud Ten pictures guys just aren't up to the task of producing a high quality film. They belong on the Hallmark channel, not in the theater.I admit, I wanted to like it, I really did. I like a good disaster/apocalypse film, but this was just awful. Nothing even happened for the first half of the film. Of course, for me the greatest sin (heh) was the use of Christian pop for the movie's soundtrack. In fact, this whole film felt more like a made for TV Hallmark movie of the week.Now, to be upfront, I liked the scenes with Nicolas Cage, because he's a veteran actor and usually puts in a good performance, and I think Chad Michael Murray did a far superior job as Buck Williams than Kirk Cameron. Of course, all Chad had to really do was act human, so not much of a stretch for most humans.Still, there were some decent scenes. I liked the near collision incident in the film; otherwise, the scenes inside the plane felt like "Airplane", but without the self-awareness. I did find one or two tender moments in those scenes: Where the millionaire talks to scared blond lady about raising his own daughter, and where Buck comforts her earlier on in the film shortly after the disappearances. Both moments had flavors of human empathy, which is what this film should have shown everywhere.Now, on to the first part of the film before I forget: Remember that first scene with the really smarmy Christian lady? Yeah, I don't like her, and if she got to heaven ahead of the kind, compassionate human beings who were left behind, then it only shows the glaring flaw in this film: be an ass, and Jesus will still take you as long as you pay him lip service. Help people, be kind, and compassionate, but without saying the magic words you're going to be left behind and you're going to face horrors which you deserve because you didn't say the magic words! Finally, there was the scene with Pastor Bruce Barnes and Chloe, and where the best line in the movie happened. I found it funny when Chloe asked Bruce where her mom and Raymie had been taken, and he replies that Jesus took them to heaven to save them. Chloe replies, "from what?!" but before he could answer, the quip shot into my own mind, which was "from himself!" Because that's the guy who is doing this. Not anyone else. The Big Man is the one setting these things in motion. It all falls to him.Of course this isn't what Bruce says, but most people watching the film will see this connection right away.In short, a very poor quality film based on a very poor interpretation of theology.

reviews.review_title: And people hate this movie... why?
reviews.content: Okay first off, Left Behind is no perfect film. There are flaws that I'll get into at the end. But talk about some biased critiquing! There is such an anti-God movement in this country, I'm surprised this movie was even made. I was expecting it to be hated... but there's really no reason for the hate.Let me explain: I am a Christian but I am deeply ashamed of the Christian films of the past. The original Left Behind movie is fine. I'm talking about the really awful, cheesy, ridiculous movies like God's Not Dead, a movie so out of touch with reality that it depicts all non-Christians as total jerks and who are completely deserving of the hardships they go through. But Left Behind doesn't do this.There is no unrealistically corny conversion at the end. The spirituality of the film isn't shoved in your face. Emphasis is put on the struggle of the characters as opposed to their spiritual journey. Judgmental Christians are depicted negatively.The biggest miracle of this film by far, however, is the subtle Nicolas Cage performance. Fans of his freakouts will be disappointed because his acting is great.My only complaints are in some of the actors. The kid who played Raymie was the worst of the bunch but he was also pretty young so I'm not going to judge him too harshly. There were a few small scenes that were unnecessary. Some of the special effects looked kind of dumb, particularly the green screen work. Fans of the book will be disappointed because it deviates a lot but I think it does that so it will appeal to all audiences instead of just Christians.I thought there could have been more spirituality but I'm glad that it was kept at a minimum because I think non-Christians can see this without being offended. Why would a loving God put people through something like this? The question is never fully answered and, honestly, I like that a lot. It allows people to make their own decision about how to see this film.I've seen plenty of awful movies. This wasn't an awful movie. The only reason Christians hate it is because it doesn't talk about the Bible as much as most would probably want. And the only reasons non- Christians hate it is because they hate anything having to do with Christianity.Get over your bias and watch this movie as a movie. I highly recommend it because it's well made and it asks a lot of good questions that can lead to some great discussions. I think if people see this with an open mind, this movie would be more positively received.And this is coming from someone who fully expected to point at it and laugh.

A 2/10 movie with a 5/10 Nic Cage performance based on a ludicrous premise done somewhat competently.The crux of all these left behind films is, even if you believe the premise it doesn't make much sense in their own universe or even theologically. Raptures may have enjoyed a long tradition in several religions, including christianity, but they're not really much of a focal point in christian eschatological teachings despite US-american christian right-wing's obsession with it. It seems like every year another pastor has 100% reliably predicted the date of the rapture, only for the date to pass and nothing continuing to happen. It's pretty hilarious from the outside, so some of that entertainment value translates to this piece of uniquely american christian propaganda.I'll give Left Behind a teensy bit of credit for not being as mean-spirited and disgusting as other christsploitation flicks and for not indulging too much in evangelical persecution complexes, but this movie is still fraught with odd beliefs delivered in the most ham-fisted preachy way.Visually the rapture is the comedic highlight and all the dramatic camera swoops over pieces of clothing lying in the dirt or on chairs surrounded by flabbergasted onlookers don't sell them as a frightening sign of the apocalypse.Apparently the whole world is sunk into chaos and tohuvabohu by this event, and we collectively as a species turned the civilisation knob all the way to Mad Max 2 in an instant, as soon as little Timmy popped out of his baseball shirt and his earthly existence.I don't doubt such an incident would cause untold grief to many, but it doesn't actually look like that many people were zoomed up into the heavens or that the ones not saved were exclusively nasty murderous criminals which would explain the hellish conditions the earth is now in.Apparently the only folks lucky enough to prove worthy were proseletizing fundamentalist christians, new-born babies, prepubescent children, all air traffic controllers worldwide and even the entirety of tele-communications satellites? This is where the theology gets really blurry and the premise wonky beyond repair, even if you were to believe it in the first place. If you actually read the bible (and I did, mind you) the rules on how to be a good person, how to be a good christian for that matter can be incredibly arbitrary (have you ever eaten shellfish? Then so long, pearly gates) and even contradictory, so good luck earning your way into heaven. Which leads to the next problem: despite popular misconception, in christian teaching the only path to the kingdom of heaven is accepting Jesus, unlike in other faiths (including abrahamitic ones like judaism) where you prove righteous through your deeds. Hence by that logic babies couldn't actually get saved and with them a substantial amount of good people who haven't accepted Jesus but are otherwise living ethical lives. So yeah, the film's premise doesn't even make sense in its own universe. This is one of the reasons ideas of a big rapture aren't prominent features in most christian denominations, it doesn't even appear in revelations as a sign of the endtimes. While Left Behind is ostensibly made as christian propaganda, it thus feels much more like christian fan fiction.However there is a smidgen of residual entertainment value in its intrinsic ridiculousness. It's not as cheap-looking as other exemplars of the genre, so you can actually physically watch it from beginning to end without gritting your teeth at every technical detail of the production. Nicolas Cage is entertaining, especially when he looks like he's forced against his will to appear in a movie, but in general the premise is beyond stupid especially if you are a christian and even subtly disgusting the more you think about it.As a very devout non-believer this was actually somewhat funny to watch though. If you're into unintentionally revealing trash flicks this might be up your alley, but come prepared, this one is getting preachy as hell. Just as a film in itself though it's a catastrophe.

It is not brilliant, but it is not crap either. Nicholas Cage gets a lot of bad press for his movies, but this I think is a better one that a lot of his latest ones. The story is of course based on the Christian 'Rapture', but that in itself is not rammed down your throat and the movie is not preachy at all. It turns outs it's just a reasonable disaster movie with a sub plot that is setup for more movies in the series as per the books it's based on. The overall acting was good, the effects reflect the movies budget and the script did okay! Not an oscar winner, but also not a bad movie!

reviews.review_title: A Movie Without a Purpose, Full of Dead Ends in the Plot
reviews.content: The worst part of this movie is that it never follows through on the story behind its primary concept (the Rapture) and it is full of characters and side plots that go nowhere.Ultimately this is a plane crash/rescue movie, not a religious or spiritual one. The whole plot could have just as easily been driven by a bad jet engine or a fuel leak. Why bother with the Rapture, the disappearing people and the ones left behind if you're never going to resolve that element of the conflict? It leads nowhere and is ultimately useless to the plot of the movie.Other time wasters and side plots that went nowhere fast - the relationship and conflict between daughter and mother. No resolution. No purpose to the conflict.The presence of Chad Murray. He serves no purpose other than to give the other actors someone to talk to. His relationship with Cassie Thomson is utterly superficial. His role as a news reporter is not necessary to advance the plot. He could have just as easily been a rock star, a doctor or a hot dog stand vendor.The passengers on the plane. Their characters and faults are partially developed, but ultimately for no purpose other than to fill time.

reviews.review_title: I'm not even religious at all...
reviews.content: But even though it seems to be universally hated, I was entertained, and that's all I ever ask of a film. I saw the original series in the early 2000s, and I wish they'd have remade all 3. Maybe it's my partiality to Mr. Cage, as I find him so believable, even in the worst roles/movies, which are nearly always carried and rescued by him. He literally becomes whatever character he portrays, and that's a real feat considering he's been in well over 100 movies! No offense to Kirk Cameron, who played the pilot in the original movie series and actually is very religious, but I really was moved by Nicholas Cage's anguished portrayal of the airline pilot. Even though I knew the story already, there was still a lot of suspense. A few of the supporting actors really good, and the rest were capable. It's too bad the script couldn't have been jazzed up a bit, because this story had a huge amount of potential. Maybe they weren't allowed to change it up. The books have a lot more detail, but they don't have Nicolas Cage. Regardless of the reason some people were taken and others were left behind (religion or if it had been something else, such as alien abduction) this film was still good for me as a thriller. The direction, cinematography and production weren't outstanding but not bad, either. The special effects, such as empty vehicles crashing and the widespread scattering of clothes and belongings, were effective and not over-used. I took a few stars away. One was taken for predictability, whether or not the viewer has read the books or seen the original movie(s). Another was taken because I felt the music was a little over-dramatic, and the song being played during the end credits sounded cheesy to me. The last was taken because the cinematography and overall production wasn't inspired or overwhelming, but only average to me. If you're very religious or just like movies with stuff decent suspense, it's not the worst way to spend a couple of hours. Pass if you expect a superb blockbuster of a movie with plot twists. You know what they say about opinions...! This one was mine, and I hope it helps somebody decide: to watch, or not to watch! This is definitely not Shakespeare, but during his era, options were limited, and he had no competition!

Hugely popular among evangelicals, the Left Behind series in fact suits a 'Heroes' or 'Lost' style TV series rather than a film. Most of the book's plot is ditched and instead a sort of 70's style aeroplane disaster movie is slightly awkwardly inserted to tie the characters together. The script is at least better than that of say '2012', treating the rapture with the same po-faced seriousness of any good Mayan prophecy. The special effects are cheaper though. The whole is better than the sum of its parts; solid direction and acting (Nick Cage is good as always, the supporting cast surprisingly winning) helps. However the film works best as a study of decent people under stress and just about winning out (as you rather hope and believe they would). As a result it has a strong redemptive streak that exceeds that of the underlying book series.

reviews.review_title: it's scifi/fantasy, anything goes, so why not Christian mythology?
reviews.content: Maybe all the negative reviews here prepared me with lowered expectations for this movie, but I liked it! It is very very far from the worst move ever as several reviews have claimed. Actually it was pretty good as a scifi/fantasy flick. I know it wasn't meant to be campy like Sharknado, but if looked at in that context it was entertaining.I think the whole Christian motif makes many people close to that religion, either pro or con, like or hate this movie. If you are ambivalent about the religious aspects, it is a pretty cool story and well portrayed.The pace of the film is good and it maintains interest. The acting is well done and there is some descent character development. Cage did a way better job than a couple of films I've seen him in recently (Rage 2014). Although far from his finest performance, he made the part believable. The dialog gets bogged down in several spots by spending too much time trying to convey a Christian value set, but it isn't too over the top preachy. And the script does give ample time to the point of view that most fundamentalist Christians are a couple sandwiches short of a picnic.The music throughout the film was horrible, gosh, just awful, but it wasn't everywhere so just ignore it.We embrace many strange concepts in movies all the time...zombies, vampires, killer computers, demons, honest politicians...well maybe that is a little too far-fetched, but talking animals, witches, gods, ghosts, hobbits, monsters, possession ...it's scifi/fantasy anything goes, so why not Christian mythology? I say give this flick a fair chance, don your Mystery Science Theater 3000 perspective and enjoy.

Nicholas Cage as Captain Steele was an excellent choice for this character. I have read all the books and his portrayal is true to the story, especially when he figures out the rapture has occurred. The action was well done and in good taste. It portrayed how one would imagine what will happen when this event occurs. The action scenes are realistic and truly scary. The scene where Chloe climbs to the top of the bridge and obviously thinks of taking her own life portrays how God's grace and intervention stops her in her tracks in a very difficult circumstance. All in all, this is an excellent movie!! Well acted and true to the original story. It does make you think about your own walk in the Lord and how bad it will truly be in the world once God's Grace is removed, but not(Thank God)His Mercy!!!

reviews.review_title: It deserves a higher rating, unfortunately its strategy just doesn't work
reviews.content: I've enjoyed the film, it's been very frustrating to me how negative most people been towards it. It seems that both secular audiences and Christian audiences are usually unhappy with it. But I think I have figured out why. And the answer is actually quite simple- for most of us, if we have something against a movie (or anything else for that matter), we're generally going to hate it no matter how good it is (we focus on the negative, and ignore the positive).There are two kinds of movies- secular films and Christian films. And sadly this movie shows that the two types just don't mix. It seems that the filmmakers decided to make an exciting, action packed, Hollywood style film with big name actors in order to attract secular audiences and show them what we Christians believe is coming- the rapture. I'm sure it worked some, but it seems that any scripture is too much for the average secular audience, no matter how exciting the movie may be. If they had portrayed the rapture as science fiction, like alien abduction, it would've had a higher rating. The movie is very exciting and well done- a fact that many people either ignore or refuse to accept because of its Christian aspect. And at the same time, many Christian audiences also dislike it because of its Hollywood style, and the fact that it only has a bare minimum of scripture.As a Christian, I've been looking forward to this movie for many years now, longer than any other film. I'm somewhat disappointed with it, but I do still enjoy it, in fact the more I watch it, the more I enjoy it, but I do wish that it had more scripture. Even for the secular audience, I think it would've helped if they had explained the rapture a little more- they give almost no explanation of what it is and why we believe it, other than the fact that it's in the Bible.I think some Christian audiences also dislike it because it's so different from the books. The original Left Behind movie was very similar to the book. I enjoy it, but they sort of covered too much, they tried to squeeze the entire first novel into it, which didn't exactly work all that well. Ironically, this time it's the exact opposite, only a very small part of the novel is covered, just the first few hours after the rapture. But it's interesting to note that both authors of the Left behind series did not like the original movie, but do like this one. I actually find that somewhat surprising. I'm not sure which film I like better. I do hope they make sequels, but the ratings probably won't be much different.

reviews.review_title: Biased opinion because I read the books first
reviews.content: So, I read the book(s) several years ago and I can remember reading the entire 3rd book in just one night. The first movie that had Kirk Cameron was pretty low budget, like something you might watch on Lifetime. I remember wondering what the movie might have been like if it had a big budget and an all star cast. Well, this movie fell a little short... actually, it fell waaaay short! As the movie began, you know those little snippets that they show where the production company shows off their name, like DreamWorks with the kid fishing from the moon, or Pixar with the dancing desk light? Well this movie started with 4 or 5 companies that I had never heard of. Next, the movie began with a weak musical score that was, again, reminiscent of a made for TV movie. The acting was pretty poor by most characters and the writing was corny at times with characters inserted that took away from the storyline... like the 'angry little person' or the senior citizens on the plane with Alzheimer's. I have to admit, movies about Aviation or the Military have to do their research to keep me from snickering. The set for the cockpit was awful, the size of the plane making a trans Atlantic flight was incorrect, the plane crossing the Atlantic that they almost collided with was even smaller. And the biggest blooper was the decision to turn around so late after the 'Event' The movie was just poor all the way around, and dragged on at times... but I did like the fact that it provoked thought and opened discussion with my son who I took with me.

I'm genuinely embarrassed for everyone involved in this film. Truly, truly terrible. Go watch paint dry, cut your toenails or try and gouge your own eyes out, anything would be preferably to watching this abomination.

Now, I'm not a fan of Nicolas Cage's tendency to overact however I do like a good post-apocalyptic thriller that, when executed well never fail to engage me from start to finish. Even a biblical thriller has potential, albeit limited, to be engaging. However, when watching Left Behind I was left with the overarching feeling that this film is actually really boring.Nicolas Cage's tendency to overact isn't actually evident here, as his character adopts a more sombre tone as a result of realising he hasn't done enough to redeem himself and will spend eternity on what is essentially a living hell. However, Cage comes across as more bored than sombre, which may be down to the fact that this film for a post-apocalyptic thriller is a needless snoozefest that delivers on none of the admittedly limited promise it has. It's also worth looking at the people, ahem, left behind, particularly one character who is left in purgatory simply for adhering to a different religion to his peers. You cannot tell me that Cage's wife who is in the midst of fanatically and dangerously flouting her beliefs is worthy of surviving the rapture either, as her character comes across as inherently unlikeable?I would recommend this film to anyone who also enjoys seeing how bad films can get without becoming a cult classic like The Room or Plan 9. Everything about this film is cringeworthy and embarrassing. Avoid.

I mean my sock draw has a more interesting life than these characters. Someone has wasted a lot or maybe very little of their money making this film and you know what? They deserve it for not reading the poor boring script. God I'm so angry I didn't turn it off. I thought surely this is going to get better, going to take off (no pun) but no. Don't watch this film ever! I have never posted a review of a film but this dribble forced me to do so. I will now spend the rest of my life protecting people from this film.

I don't understand all the negative reviews about this movie. It is a good thing that I didn't read them first. Maybe these views are the results of cynics, atheists, personal transparency, people afraid of the truth, or watching the movie on a low quality screen. My friend who read the series of books the movie is based on also loved the movie.I didn't focus so much on the acting as the story line, but I did think Martin Klebba's antagonist remarks were hilarious. I thought Jordan Sparks did an amazing job. Chad Michael Murray is a hotty even though his super hero character is not all that believable. In the movie I laughed, I cried, I felt fear and I cheered. At the end of the movie, everyone (at least 50 people) in the theater stood up and clapped. I lived a life so far from both sides of the coin. As a child I could drink water from a stream in a forest not far from my home. We went Trick or Treating without chaperoned well into the night. At 13 years of age a single murder in Chicago made headline news. Politicians ran for office to improve our country not for self-indulgence and greed. Education was something I enjoyed and valued, not forced and a source of major stress for both student and educator. Animal abuse was not part of our vocabulary. We believed in our leaders and a future for our country. All this change has taken place in just shy of 60 years. A downward spiraling change at this rate of speed cannot sustain itself. The movie shows our world as it is today with greed, self-indulgence, theft, killing, selfishness. To me, this is a reality check. Maybe for others, this is just business as usual.Growing up as a Catholic I am not well-versed in the Bible. After seeing the movie I joined a Church with an intense Bible Study group. I hope this movie will have an equal effect on others seeking the truth.

I can understand every opinion on this movie. Bad, good and people laughing at it. I'm the latter. I'm guessing they were being serious about this being a possibility so maybe that's lost on me but at the end of the day, I had a seriously good laugh so for me, it was a success!! Wouldn't put me off Nicolas Cage or Lea Thompson in the future either. Not every movie is perfect and they didn't write it (I assume!). Open your mind and have a laugh with this one!

Nicolas Cage sometimes does some good films. He is a great actor but falls fail to choosing very bad scripts at times (for example, Ghost Rider!) and I'm afraid he's done it again!This film is nothing but blatant Christian propaganda and the message is clear; unless you are a child or a Christian, you are doomed. Terrible film, terrible acting and a terrible message. What the hell were you thinking Nic (yes, there's a clever pun in there somewhere)!?The running past something as it explodes purely for effect, the tight shirt on the air hostess, the angry little dwarf, the ladies eye-candy hero which really made no difference to the story-line... need I go on? Ultimately, the Christian message is embarrassing and if I were religious (which I'm not!), I'd feel very ashamed of this blatant rubbish!Avoid it, don't waste your time. No wonder it flopped at the box office and never made it to the UK! Keep it out thanks as people in the UK don't buy this crap!

Like ... what did Vic Armstrong smoke when directing this movie?

Just the worst experience i had in years! Everything is bad: the idea, the screenplay, the acting, the logic, the psychology, the special effects,...

reviews.review_title: Definitely worth seeing on the big screen
reviews.content: Great action movie with good acting and a great story line. It tracked well with the book. They did a really nice job of bringing the story to life. I liked how they balanced humor, action, spirituality and suspense in one very entertaining movie. It was interesting to see how the characters present in the beginning differed from those who remained at the end. It was also cool to see the transformation of some of the main characters as they realize what had happened and why. Nicholas Cage did a great job portraying Captain Steele. The other actors also did a nice job of portraying the other characters and they all fit with how I pictured them from the book. I also really liked the music in the film. I hope they continue with sequels. I can't wait to see how they portray what happens next.

This is the WORST movie ever by a LONG LONG LONG way. It's so bad you've gotta laugh at it or your brain will hurt. I had to take a long shower afterwards I just felt violated by subjecting myself to it (Netflix - what were you thinking?)
 Almost every line is a cliche, you just want ALL the cast to disappear, and the plot (what plot?) is ridiculous. 
And there's no beginning, no middle and no ending! 
I thought it would be perfect material for a (Airplane/Flying High) spoof spin-off, but it's a spoof of itself already!
Best watched very drunk with a group of (even drunker) friends - and ROFL!
The original was 500 times better! Why not continue the series in stead of redoing what was great in the first place. 👎👎

After watching this, you will regret the time you wasted. Please, do yourself a favour: choose another movie to watch. I was left feeling angry. Angry that nick Cage was involved and It has dropped my estimation of him. Angry that it got made without someone stopping it and saying "really?" Before it was released. Oh, hang on, this was a joke. It has just dawned on me. Aww, shucks, you guys!But, as a movie, the joke is not executed very well.Look, shoot happens. And this is an example of it. I am an avid movie fan, and I often read the reviews and I was really shocked at how many negative posts there were. I also found the negative posts prompted me to make this review. I am disappointed that people made this a debate about Christianity and Athieism. This is a film like many others exploring the possibilities of ideas and beliefs. My suggestion is watch IT, and form your own opinion as its your opinion and enjoyment that matter the most. I think some of the negative comments are totally unwarranted and unnecessary. Enjoy!

Here is the problem with this movie - it is based on an exceptional Christian novel series; of which the first 10 books are excellent.If the movie is doing the books justice then the "Left Behind," did it's job, kind of. The whole purpose of the first book was to establish the main characters, set the catalyst for the stories "the Rapture," and lay the ground work for the rest of the books, namely dealing with repentance, and being witnesses to the tribulation.Sadly the movie spent far too much time on the plane and not enough time dealing with the rise of Nicolae Carpathia and the formation or the tribulation force. This leads me to believe that the rest of the books will not be made into movies.Only Hollywood knows why they would do this. . .

How the H... did Nicolas Cage end up in this crappy movie. Not much to say. Very bad acting, very poor story. The lines, and dialog are amateurish. sometimes it's like watching a school play - no method acting in this movie. Cloth changes from cut to cut, situations who just happen to be in the very right condition - all the time... the store never actually catches on and the end is just a big laugh. This is a religious propaganda movie and i guess we now know where Nicolas stand on this issue??? All they do is trying to make people, who do not believe in god, in a specific way, very scared. Awful. The script - horrible!The ultimate story line - believable, however, the actors and plot in between, - unbelievable. The daughter, got on my last nerve and was ANNOYING! Nicolas Cage - who would do what he did in this day and age based on security procedures. The crash landing - Give me a break! The actors - Dear Lord! Worst 2 hrs of our day and we had to clean our house and storage area for the entire afternoon.The ultimate story line could have been scripted so much better. I hope the director reflects on this debut and the music which accompanied the movie - We still can't believe we watched this -- AWFUL!

reviews.review_title: This is NOT Science Fiction ! Worse ending than - "It was all a dream!"
reviews.content: My wife and I have just wasted time watching this RUBBISH! Don't bother trying to think up an explanation for the strange events! The so-called "Answer" will appal you. This is NOT Science Fiction. This is NOT a thriller. This is NOT a comedy. This is NOT intended to be seen by anybody with any intelligence. It insults your intelligence, it insults your humanity! Watch "Andy Pandy" instead, the plot of that is more intelligent, and is intended for young children! At least at the end, Andy gets back into his basket for a lovely sleep! Remember all those TV Shows where you spent month after month, trying to work out what was going on, such as "Lost", "The Prisoner", "Under The Dome", etc. where at the end there was never a real 'Answer'. This is NOT like that! At the end there IS an 'answer'. an unacceptable one!

This is probably the worst remake I've seen to date. Obviously, most of you have seen the negative postings, so I am going to touch on some things that weren't mentioned and try to keep it brief.I'll start off by saying, there's something to be said about low budget independent films, because usually the hunger is there so you get a better gem of a film. The original was just more genuine, scripted better and performed better. If you have seen the original, seeing this crapfest should really make you appreciate it more. If you haven't seen the original you owe it to yourself to make up for seeing this mess.First off, when I heard this was going to be based on strictly the rapture happening, I knew it was going to be long and tedious and boy I wasn't disappointed. It took about 25 minutes to get to the rapture. It was painstakingly slow. Then we the rapture happened it was even more unnecessarily long. Now, everyone knows that Nicholas Cages style of acting is better suited for some roles than others, this one definitely was not it. Forget the fact that physically he is no where near Ray's description. He was flat, unemotional and just seemingly uninterested in whom he was portraying. Watch Brad Johnson's portrayal of Ray Steele and you'll see what I mean. It wasn't just the writing and cornball dialog, but Nic really acted like he didn't want to be there.Love or hate Kirk Cameron, his performance as Buck was probably his best performance period. He gets a lot of hate because he's perceived as a religious zealot, which may or may not be true, but at least with his portrayal you got a level of sincerity and genuineness which made his character believable, that can not be taken from him.I absolutely hated Bucks portrayal in here and it wasn't so much as Murray's acting as it was the writing for his character, but it still came off as, I'm here for the pay check. Plus, his almost vainglorious introduction bothered me because Buck wasn't like that in the original film nor the books. Words escape me about what to say about Chloe's character, because her whole introduction and persona felt rushed and disengaging, nothing like Janaya Stephens. She was just bitter and surly for no reason. I was sitting there like huh?While we're on the subject of Buck and Chloe, I reallllly HATED the way he and Chloe were introduced. The entire scenario was unrealistic. A woman buys a Christian book and approaches Buck on his faith in GOD or lack thereof and then Chloe interrupts the conversation with her anti- GOD speech? No one does that. Jehovah's witnesses don't even do that and they're incredibly invasive. Buck was hitting on her hard and she came off like a floozy. That's not how they met in the original or books. It was really unnecessarily drawn out too.I don't know who played Pastor Barnes, but he can't lace Clarence Gilyards Sunday best shoes. This guy was just plain bad. I don't know how he managed to do this, but he was able to overact and underact simultaneously.Hattie was basically portrayed as a slut in here, which she wasn't in the original or the books. Plus she and Buck knew each other which apparently in here they didn't.The original isn't without its shortcomings, but it was a modern day masterpiece compared to this uninspired, cluster rushed, poorly written stinker. Please watch the original.

reviews.review_title: Do yourself a favor and go watch Sharknado. At least then you would be entertained
reviews.content: Very avid movie watcher of all genres, however, this is my official first movie review. It is not so much of a review as a warning to others who found themselves as bored as I was over the holidays and thought I'd try Left Behind a chance...even though it had received such low ratings. I try not to be completely persuaded by others' opinions before I give a movie a view, but in this specific case Viewer Take Warning! Movie starts super slow and the acting on the Disney Channel is better then what I just witnessed. After about 40 minutes into the movie people are suddenly missing after a bright flash of light. What remains are all of the non believers. Aka almost everyone in the movie except for the children and a select few adults. Chaos ensues both on the plane and around the globe. It is here where I turned the movie off because the effects, acting, script, and plot were too amateur to continue wasting my vacation day on. Do yourself a favor and go watch Sharknado...at least you will be guiltily entertained from start to finish!

reviews.review_title: watch the movie and think about as it happens
reviews.content: first of all this movie is Sci-Fi and judge this way , i am not going to give full spoil here , there are a lot of movies and series which the base of all was to believe in God , this one is too. for example they talk about earthquake , some believes it is god's work , and some says this is because of environment . In this movie these kind of conversations or events start and end very fast. my guess is this could be a mini-series for this kind of story . after all , I've seen a lot of movies which deserve a 3 of 10 , but this movie is not one of them. it makes you entertain for at least 1 hour and 10 minutes to tell you what's going on , so I give a 6 .

God-awfulScript is terrible. It's a new genre of sci-fi biblical, which is just uncomfortable to sit through. It's a ridiculous stretch of the imagination. The acting is horrible.It has MAJOR Christian undertones, and more along the fundamentalist/evangelical kind. It's not for mainstream, and it kind of makes you blush with how corny and cheesy it is. I like thrillers, and this is NOTHING like that at all. The movie is like listening to your crazy evangelical grandmother rant about the apocalypse for two and a half hours, it's that obvious. Everything about the movie just seems so forced and contrived. It's really as terrible as it sounds.

For those of you who are interested in the study of the art of film, and need an exercise in calibration and a baseline with which to tell good from bad, I can wholeheartedly recommend this movie as the best way to finally and definitively answer the question "what is the worst movie of all time?".Nic Cage must either be dead broke, owe someone the favour to end all favours, or else some Producer has his children held captive. A more wretched pile of steaming sputum was never coughed into existence, including during the 7 years that the Black Death swept across Europe. The script was woefully primitive; better dialogue could easily have been written by encouraging a disease-riddled crow to randomly peck away at a typewriter for 5 minutes.The acting was pathetic. Alarm bells should have rung for me when I saw a supporting cast comprising Chad Michael-Murray, some girl from Neighbours, a former American Idol contestant, and Marty McFly's mum off of Back to the Future. The special effects looked like they were done on a Spectrum ZX81. The pacing and editing was turgid and lumbering, the soundtrack was uninspiring, amateurish and jarring, even the lighting was dull, flat, and caused me to squint like a coal miner resurfacing after a 40-hour shift. The humour, or attempts at it, were uncomfortable and awkward, centering on a running gag of mis-trust between a Muslim and a Little Person getting angrier and angrier with each other which climaxes at the end with the Muslim booting the Midget down the inflatable escape slide of the plane. It sounds like it could be funny, even just for the slapstick. It isn't. This affront to celluloid isn't even in the "so bad it's good" bucket, as even Christian film reviewers (for this IS the story of The Rapture after all) slammed this movie quicker than Judas turns snitch at the sight of some silver.If someone offers you the chance to watch this movie, or as I did you see it pop up on Netflix and get suckered in by the Sci-Fi sounding synopsis and decide to give it a shot, I can highly recommend taking yourself into your back garden and liberally beating yourself around the genitals with a half-brick. It will be a less painful experience.

I decide to watch Left Behind for several reasons. 1. I enjoy stories that challenge belief systems 2. I enjoy stories that ask you to reevaluate your current paradigm 3. I enjoy stories that offer a compelling message 4. I enjoy action movies.This movie met none of my 4 expectations. The acting is terrible. The script is terrible. The quality of effects is terrible. Considering the message of the book this film fails on every level. It is not even a good piece of fundamentalist propaganda. It is possible to make a film that appeals to a Christian audience that offers a message without lowering the bar of production value and story telling. Charlton Heston's "Ten Commandments" was better than this. Even an agnostic theist like myself believes the traditional Christian audience deserves better.

reviews.content: Without doubt the most laughable film I have seen for a long time. The script is truly appalling and is only surpassed by the most dreadful acting ever. At the critical point in the movie where she is asked to address all the passengers, immediately after her lip gloss has been refurbished. Brilliant!! Lip gloss is obviously key to the plot and sums up the film.No idea what Nicolas Cage or Lea Thomson were thinking!! Totally pointless, useless and nonsensical. Don't waste a minute of your time unless you want a laugh.The religious references are too pathetic to mention. I just pray there will never be a "Left behind 2"

This one is OK but not as good as the original. They spend too much time on the airplane instead of moving on into the story. No offense the actors did great but who ever wrote the script did not do their research. All of the Focus was on three people. They left out a lot of what was going on in the rest of the world. Nothing about the Anti-Christ! Nothing about the world in general! Typical just like Man of Steel and Ninja Turtles just enough to make it look good but no real substance to follow the true meaning. They strayed to far from the book or the original movie! Now if they plan on making a whole series out of it then maybe they will have something but seems like they tried to push the true point back typical do not want to offend non0believers!

I signed up to review this.. im blown away by how bad this movie is. And dispite the onslaught of terrible acting from pretty much everyone, somehow Nic still shines like a beacon determined to out-terrible the crowd, although he does fall just short of his daughter who takes the crown of crapness. The writing is terrible, cinematography is stale as old bread, and i cant even talk about the writing without getting mad. This is the movie version of Rebecca Blacks "hit" Friday.

Although the idea of the movies is interesting and stating the start of the Apocalypse according to Luke's Bible: "Two men will be in the field; one will be taken and the other will be left." (luke 17:36), but the unprofessional movie script and acting made it unclear, unorganized, and hard to understand.

reviews.review_title: Didn't expect much, but was still disappointed
reviews.content: Pretty much from the opening scene I knew this movie was going nowhere. First of all what is up with the background music in this film? Its like they picked the most generic music from 90's made-for-TV movies they could find and inserted it into literally EVERY scene. Background music should be subtle and seamless. Luckily for the viewers, we don't have to figure out for ourselves when a heartwarming, sad, or suspenseful scene is happening. The blunt and strangely loud background music will let you know how to feel very quickly.Second of all, did they just go with the first take for every scene? Personally I think Nick Cage gets a bad rap most of the time for taking on terrible roles, but this was bad even for him. I couldn't shake the feeling that I was watching a bad soap opera. How they even spent $16m on this thing is beyond me.I'm generally not too critical of movies, since I have an idea of what I'm getting into before I see a movie, and I take it for what it is. But in this case it was just so amateurish and rough. Its hard to believe the people that made this movie watched the final cut and said "Yep, we did it guys, that's a wrap!" Its just awful on so many levels. Not even taking into account the story line which is a whole other discussion altogether.For some reason nobody on a a plane full of Americans (who are presumably 75% Christian) have ever heard of the rapture lol. Hey lets put a Muslim guy in there too. We'll show how they aren't all bad, but so sorry you picked the wrong God to worship. No heaven for you! Plus we also learned God isn't particularly fond of little people or the mentally impaired. To sum it up, after all is said and done, if you literally believe in the rapture I'm sure you'll still like it even with all its flaws. And if you're just looking for a moderately entertaining movie to rent for a buck, do yourself a favor and rent Calvary instead.

Having read reviews before watching this I had low expectations but it's not actually that bad. Yes the plot could be slightly better and the film does come across as "Budget" at times. The main character is a pilot played by Nicolas Cage and I thought he done well considering. (NO SPOILERS) The film is basically themed around the Rapture where loads of people just disappeared into thin air only leaving there belongings behind. No one knows why this has happened apart from a minority who are seen as mad or going mad. Most of the film is set on a plane where the crew and passengers are confused but have to deal with technical problems with the plane and they have to try and get back to an airport whilst they are over the Atlantic. This is basically a Mystery/Aviation film with a little bit of Action as well. (That's the way it came across to me) At times the film came across as a little bit narrow minded and didn't have as much action as I thought it would. I'm not sure if this was a budget movie but it did come across that way sometimes and I felt they could have made a bigger impact, for example there could have been scenes showing the global impact of people going missing just so you got more of a sense this was global rather than being concentrated on the plane all the time. Overall an OK film and not as bad as you think its going to be

I imagined this movie was what happened after thanos snapped his finger and half the population disappeared. Then showing us a realistic viewpoint from religious nuts that think it was rapture. That way the movie was slightly better and made more sense.

It's worth watching if you are bored out of your mind. It's like the made for TV sci if movies; some of the scenes are brilliant, some are corny as hell. The film that just keeps on giving. Oscar winning performances all round. Better special effect than the matrix. You need to see this film twice. Stop reading a watch now. Not to be missed.

reviews.review_title: Religious nonsense and bad film-making aside - not bad
reviews.content: This movie has the perfect ingredients to be the epitome of awfulness and deserving of a meta-critic score of 12: Nicolas Cage, poor script, poor film-making and religious nonsense. I, as an Atheist, was surprisingly not really phased by the religious aspect of the film. After watching I did not think 'oh no I need to believe in God otherwise I'll burn in hell' but I did think that maybe I should be more aware of my actions. For example, in the future I'll make sure I don't have the short temper of the angry little dwarf. The moral aspect of the film was flawed though because the Muslim man was arguably the kindest man in the whole film yet he was left in the chaotic world which shows what is wrong with some religion.There was a moment in the film though, where Cage was theatrically tearing up on the phone to his daughter who was at the top of the bridge, and a tear ran down my face. I found that moment in the film compelling and profound, no matter what has happened, the love between a father and a daughter is one of the strongest bonds in the world. Much stronger than the will of a delusional bearded man in the sky.I actually feel that this was not a Christian film, but an ambiguously atheistic one exposing the ills of religion and that strong characters such as Ray, Buck and Irene can defy against it in in fire and blood and anguish.I maintain my view that role choice doth not maketh the actor and that despite the awful films he finds himself in, Nicolas Cage is a good actor and equal in genius to his uncle - Francis Ford Coppola. This film would be much more awful without Cage.

Saw this movie last night with my wife and daughter. I was expecting a great, bible based, movie about something that is very exciting to Christian believers, the Rapture. What I saw was a very mediocre Hollywood "B" movie that hit a single, instead of a grand slam; pretty much in all respects. Leaving the theater, I was asking myself, "How could a movie about something so big, be so bland?" Speculating, it may be that too much money was spent on the A list actor and not enough on development of the screenplay. I know there are many non-believers in Hollywood, and what appears to have happened is that this movie was influenced by that element so much that major themes that would have made the movie more interesting, were simply avoided or left-out. I enjoyed the performances of Cassie Thompson (playing Chloe Steele) and Nicky Whelan (playing Hattie Durham) but overall, I believe this movie had so much more potential and left the theater feeling like Hollywood did not really present much substance about the Rapture other than it's depiction of it's occurrence.

reviews.review_title: No Point, No thing at all
reviews.content: Went in to the movie yesterday with my wife. Recommended to her as she is a better Christian and supposed she would love it. I wrote this review on her behalf. And I QUOTE: Never did I've seen such a troubling movie, in this I mean "the movie end before it begins". Literally, as in the end of the movie, someone said "This is just the beginning....". reviews.review_title: It is a good movie showing a small segment of the people left behind after the rapture
reviews.content: When the rapture actually happens, it will not happen the way anyone predicts, including this movie. All who know how it will happen will be shown to be wrong. This movie follows one family from several hours before the rapture to 4 or so hours after the rapture. One of the family members is a pilot in the air, in a plane. The other is his daughter on the ground. Both are trying to deal with the events of the rapture. As a window into the lives of this family, it was a good movie. On the plane they mostly dealt with the first class passengers. They had to compress a 4 hour flight into a 2 hour movie. If you are looking for character development, that is not what this movie was about. This movie was a small glimpse into the lives of a few people after the rapture occurred. as such, it was a good movie. The movie presents the pre-tribulation view of the rapture. People slowly remember their Bible lessons from their youth, which after 4 hours, people might actually do. It was clever to put a Muslim on the plane and it is customary in movies like these to have a pastor be left behind. The pastor was a bit less broken up than I would think he would be. All babies and children (they do not specific what age) are saved, which is gracious. "millions" are saved, which presents a very narrow road. Census data shows over a billion people who call themselves Christian. So, generally speaking, it got the point across. It was entertaining, it glorified God and it presented the Gospel. Remembering that the only people speaking are unsaved, I think they presented the Gospel as good as unsaved people could. So I recommend this movie for Christians, but especially for those who do not believe. The rapture will happen...soon

reviews.review_title: This was not at all good; but nowhere near as bad as has been made out.
reviews.content: I'm a former Christian and now a vocal atheist. I read the reviews for this movie and out of sheer stubborn curiosity I had to see what a disaster Nic Cage had gotten involved in.Truthfully, I think many other atheists have been a little unfair. Yes, this film wears its 'holier than thou' on it's sleeve, yes the story is pants and yes, definitely among Mr. Cage's worst efforts ever.But...The acting is, well, okay. The cinematography and direction is also okay and the music choices, while certainly awful in two places (both Christian songs,) were nowhere near as bad as has been made out and even, occasionally, appropriate for many scenes. (A sinister yet choral piece during the actual rapture and tense, dramatic music for the finale being decent examples.)Which just leaves the writing. Well, when all is said and done, its based on a book series that was designed to preach to the choir and the film was only ever really going to see mass numbers in the Christian community, so non-Christians, agnostics and Atheists could not help but feel preached to.That being said, the film opens with an evangelist being quite effectively 'shut-down' by a non-believer right from the start and, apart from dad 'hinting' at mom's new-found craziness and the daughter almost getting preached at by said mom, there's nary a mention of religion until about 3/4 of the way through and, even then, no-one yells 'you have to accept Jesus Christ as your personal Lord and Saviour to reach the Kingdom of Heaven!' at any point. Oh, there's one almost guilty pleasure at the sight of a Christian Pastor who was not saved and I couldn't help thinking that, in reality, there's going to be hell of a lot of supposed Christians with eggs on their faces if the Rapture was really going to happen as their 'lip-service' Christianity is rewarded like this guy.Truthfully, apart from the insulting way that the writers and director insinuate that those who have not been saved by God are almost all morally deficient in one way or another - rioters, armed robbers, bag snatchers, violent angry bystanders, philanderers, Muslims (not my take, theirs), capitalists, conspiracy nuts etc - the story is just a plain old interpretation, with a sprinkling of family drama and action, of 2000 year old Biblical hog-wash. The way it was interpreted, acted, filmed etc was nowhere near great but it was also quite watchable... just.

reviews.review_title: A bad film with deservedly low user rating
reviews.content: The first attempt to make a film of Tim Lahaye's book was made in 2000, with 1/4 of this film's budget. It has quite a low user rating (4.6) mainly because non-believers didn't like the Christian fundamentalist aspects of the story. But compared to this film, it tells A LOT more story, is A LOT more dramatic and generally works as a reasonable piece of story telling, regardless of whether you can believe the main scenario or not. By comparison, this film tells virtually nothing of the main theme of the book (and the earlier film), explains nothing about the views of the 'crazy' Christians, and even has to be politically correct by showing a Muslim being all nicey-nicey to other passengers. There is little or poor character development, no-one I felt any real sympathy for - Cage's character seems a weak-willed mushy non- entity; the stewardess (Hattie) that he supposedly has been having an affair with is unattractive and incompetent; a spoiled daughter; an illiterate wife... the list could go on! It's low rating (3.1 at time of writing) is more than it deserves! Millions of people are supposed to have vanished at the same time - this would result in chaotic catastrophe on a vast scale, but we see next-to-nothing of this! Surely some CGI could have produced massive vehicle pile-ups, maybe a few downed aircraft, or the odd Then the daughter supposedly in heroine mode, lights a signal for her father to land the plane, by setting light to a few fuel barrels - in the middle of chaos which would have had hundreds of fires burning, that you get just a glimpse of right near the end! There are so many faults in the film due I presume to poor or non- existent research, that it doesn't even make a half- decent air- disaster movie. Look at the 'Goofs' section, you'll see what I mean. What a rubbish waste of $16,000,000 !!!

The main reason why I wanted to see this movie is cause of the book adaptation. I knew that it wouldn't be exactly like the book, cause lets face it, no movie is exactly like the book. However, other than a few common things, this was nothing like the book.Here are the Similarities between Left Behind book and Left Behind movie:Irene becomes a devout Christian. - Many people disappear during The Rapture, including Irene and Rayford Jr. - Chloe is in College. - Buck Williams is actually on the plane.This is where the similarities end. Now onto the differences:Movie - Chloe comes home from college on a surprise birthday visit before Rapture. Book - Chloe doesn't come home till after the Rapture.Movie - Rayford Steele's Plan is in the air for the entire movie. Book - Rayford isn't in the air the entire book. After three chapters, he is at the airport going home.Movie - Chloe witnesses her brother Raymond Jr. disappear. She finds her mother gone at home. Book - Rayford is the one that actually finds his wife and son gone from the world.Movie - Rayford is cheating on his wife with Hattie Durham (she doesn't even know he is married till later). Book - Rayford never cheated on his wife. When he got up to see Hattie, the Rapture had happened so he never cheated on his wife.I myself am not going to watch the movie (got the plot from another site) cause of how different it is from the book. reviews.review_title: They need to make the next sequel, but need to listen to feedback!!
reviews.content: OK here's the deal. These books were so amazing I (like millions of ppl) seriously have been waiting years for this movie. These were the best most compelling books I have ever read, and I read everything. I waged my own mini social media campaign with the production co, book writers etc to try to ensure they didn't make it cheesy, low budget like the last one and like every Christian themed current-times movie (they do OK on the ones from biblical times). I am rating it very high simply so that they will get plenty of traffic to the theater so that they will continue as planned and make the next one from the series of books. I am assuming that the next one will be vastly better once they take in the critiques and feedback from this one. The pro's were it kept your interest, the plane scenes were decent in terms of suspense and the acting improved as the movie progressed. My expectations were low and I'm not sure why I have to have low expectations except that based on the past 20 years of movies with any kind of religious theme, they have this odd propensity to come out like cable TV movies with poor acting and poor effects. No clue why because the Christianish movies always do well at the box office even though the viewers cringe through them. Please give us something to RAVE about just once!! So here are my gripes: 1) why oh why do they always have to portray the Christian character in the movie like some flowery, simplistic, somewhat strange, unlikeable character? In real life that is so far off from whats true. Why cant they have had the mother as an intelligent, strong, dynamic career woman that was desperately trying to ensure her family was informed and prepared for what she knew was coming? Everyone I know in Corporate America is a Christian and I have never come across one remotely like the mother in this film. Instead Leah Thomson's character was so wimpy, over acting, not real, whiny and annoying that you could see clearly why she was unable to persuade her family in any direction. Someone that has strong convictions does not come across like that, believe me. I could have recommended a slew of women I know that they could have used to blow that role out of the park. 2) Why does the daughter/non Christian have to be boiling- over angry at God and anyone that believes?? The realty is most non Christian's aren't like Chloe's character at all, and wouldn't be yelling at their mom for believing, and yelling at random ppl in the airport for believing, they are just PASSIVE, no real strong opinion either way- so her character would have been more believable as just a 20- something girl busy with her life, no time to really focus on God with all her other priorities and thinking her mom is just too into the bible for her taste. 3) Why cant a Christian movie ever have any heart wrenching, dramatic, tear jerker, meaningful, moments? I'm talking about the scene in Forest Gump where he buries Jenny and talks to her grave about their son or when Lt Dan screams at God from the sail of the boat. Or the scene in Shawshank where Morgan Freeman sits down at the stone wall and reads the note he digs up from under the rock. Actually put Morgan Freeman in the sequel because his voice alone adds depth and drama to any movie involving GOD. That's what this movie needed- it was way too focused on the chaos of ppl disappearing and didn't include one moving, jolting message or emotional scene that brings you to your knees, when the book was FULL of those!! Nicholas Cage was a little to wamsy pamsy to be Rayford Steel, the character needed to be much more strong, authoritative, charismatic. Buck was good. American Idol girl was not, Scene with gun was way too long and awkward. Little person was good. Need more normal characters next time, please. They need a panel of critics that are not involved with movie industry but are nonetheless movie going experts that can consult with them throughout production on what works and what doesn't. I literally could have advised them down to the expressions on the faces of the actors as to what worked and what needed to change. So I'm giving it an 8 simply because I wasn't as disappointed as I thought I'd be but still so annoyed that I have to have lowered expectations on a movie based on books that sold over 40 mill. Cant steven spielberg make the sequel? If it wasn't based on these phenomenal books attempting to deliver a super important message Id likely had given it a 5 on the 'real movie rating' scale....

reviews.review_title: Not as bad as some are saying....
reviews.content: Plotwise, the movie starts out slow and irrelevant. Given I had not seen the trailer, the sudden vanishing of people suddenly increased it's appeal. It got me all interested in some sort of survival based storey-line.... well I was disappointed.The Christian inspired ending was even more disappointing. I'm not specifically religious and in this world where God does not step in and start answering prayers, it seems a bit of a cop-out. That only ending I like less is where "it was all a dream".For acting, Cage was his usual expressive self. Thomson and Murray were quite fair.... but there was also the other cast members that felt almost as if they were not trying and just going through the motions.Effects, scenes, sets and camera work were all reasonable. Overall it's not a bad movie and does not deserve the slating it is getting - I have seen far, far worse ("Doomsday 2012"). It's not perfect and I will avoid watching it again, but I also do not regret seeing this movie once.

Not gonna lie. I'm a Christian and I know the whole story behind this movie very well (not to mention I even adhere to the real biblical content), but even I thought it sucked. The original version of this movie from 2000 was waaaaay better. That tells you something that over a decade later, they did a remake that was 10x worse. 2 thumbs down. I was even trying to be optimistic while watching it, but was let down over and over. Yikes.

reviews.content: I do not understand why so many people hate this film so much. Afte 6 years, i still like it. General idea and plot is very nice and i do not see serious reasons to give negative evaluation for performance as well.

This review contains spoiler, read if you've already seen it. You have to know the biblical account of the end of the world to fully appreciate this movie. After the people disappear, the rest are doomed. There is no hope for them no matter how much they achieve throughout the film, because the ones (according to the bible) who were to be saved have already been taken to heaven. The fact that this may truly be the future of mankind and the futility of the success at the end make this worse than any horror film to me and I cry every time, especially when the main girl climbs up to the top of the bridge, as I can relate to her feelings of fear and not being able to go on just waiting for certain death. There isn't really an ending to this, but the reason for it, I think, is because the ending would simply be them trying to survive until they die and go to hell. One could argue that they should have shown us the broken seals and catastrophes that are meant to happen in the last days, but that would be a different film. this film may not necessarily deserve a 10 but it certainly deserves better than 3.1

reviews.review_title: Completely plausible if you believe in the Word of God
reviews.content: I did not read the book and I resisted seeing this movie. Any person has to come a LONG way in their walk with Jesus Christ and understand the Will of God and surrender to the Will of God in order to understand this movie. If you understand that your thinking is not necessarily His thinking; you surrender your Will to His; He has a specific plan for your life; and you follow Him in a simple faith like a child; then, and only then will you understand that this is plausible. Will such a possible event happen soon? I believe that to be true. The writing and acting are completely realistic. As Esther said to Miriam as they were leaving the Valley of the Lepers in the 1959 movie, "Ben-Hur," "The world is more than we know." God, Jesus Christ/Yeshua Hamashiach, and the Word of God are all more than we know. However, it is possible to know a great deal and believe in your heart the words of truth He spoke when He walked among us.

reviews.review_title: Christian Elitist BS. Animals and Muslims go to hell?
reviews.content: I was raised Christian. I believe in God. And this was the most atrocious piece of rubbish I have ever gotten the misfortune of watching on a Sunday afternoon. Animals don't go to heaven? Muslims don't go to heaven? Making all the cast that got 'left behind' look extra bad so you know for a fact they will never get in? WHAT??This movie helps set religion back in ways no overexcited self proclaimed Jesus wannabe cult leader can. Thank God the script was awful, it comes as a consolation knowing it is next to impossible to take this movie seriously when my 3 year old niece puts up a better performance at drama- time in kindergarten. I have never bothered writing a review on IMDb but this movie feels like its deliberately trying to grate on all 'inferior' people and religions. Nicholas, what on earth, Heaven and beyond were you thinking???

If you like airline disaster movies, you might like this one. If you read the books, you will be wondering where the story went. The main characters are there, but except for Chloe Steele, there is no depth to them. The first book does have Rayford Steele as a pilot when the rapture occurs, but he lands it without major incident and then we meet other major characters and learn what really happened. The book has 25 chapters, but this movie pretty much stops at Chapter 3. If you know what the rapture is, you will be disappointed. If you don't know what the rapture is, you will be confused. If you're looking for a clear gospel message, you probably won't find it here. It's like they took the main characters and one small scene from the plane, and almost totally rewrote it. VERY DISAPPOINTED!! With a couple of exceptions, the acting was mediocre.

The movie makes you think about what is now considered "normal and okay" a lot. Most of the people giving a one star rating did not understand the movie.
It's perspective on how the worlds end would begin.

reviews.review_title: Dangerous and unbiblical. Keep your kids away from this movie
reviews.content: It is stunning how theologically incorrect this franchise is, and frankly it is very dangerous in it's presentation of the end times. I think many young christians have been very mislead by thus movie, and older christians are likely to treat as if it is at all realistic. Several bible verses indicate a post-tribulation rapture, such as the olivet discourse, (matthew 24) wherein Christ indicates that prior to his "gathering of his elect from the four winds" the whole world will "see him coming with the clouds of heaven.". According to pre-trib theology, Jesus will secretly zap up all true believers prior to his return, but according to the bible, Jesus' return is synonymous with the rapture.

reviews.review_title: It's hard to put your finger on this one..
reviews.content: The title and description of this movie are awesome. It's a great concept because this concept could reach alot of people: believers, science fiction lovers, thriller lovers, fantacy lovers, etc.. Unfortunately the movie clearly didn't turn out so well because it won't spark any interest of any group that's interested in the concept.One big reason for this was that the script is written poorly because there's a lack of thought that went into it. Think of these "millions" of people that dissapeared while this'd only be around 1/2000 people on earth?! Maybe it's just me, but the street was full of the weirdly foulded clothing of vanished people. Another example would be the poor terms used to just save some time in writing the script such as the plane that could not climb because of some defect that doesn't even exist?! Oh yeah, almost forgot, a plane's collision mid-air and face-to-face would probably end differently realisticly speaking.. Oh nevermind, the explanation of that is even covered in the script: "oh we were lucky". Not only was there a lack of thought that went into the script, they just forgot to add the developing feature of the characters. Think of any character. I don't recall any character changing in a significant way. Maybe you could call the apology of the captain to his daughter and wife a development, but I'd say he just learned from a mistake he'd make again.Ok it's clear that the script was written poorly and that they just forgot to add a bunch of stuff, lets talk about the actors. They look like me trying to pretend that I like a present I got that I really don't like. Ofcourse in the movie this effect is reversed: most actors are trying to look sad while they realize that the movie is turning out as a complete miscarriage. Oh just as a sidenote: the lighting, filming and graphics are just trash. I could do the lighting better personally with my samsung device that has no flashlight app on it installed. I could do the filming better without a camera. I could do the graphics better by drawing them by hand. An example of this horrible filming is probably that, at one point, you can physically see that a drone is struggeling to film straight with the wind blowing it away. However, the movie was still enjoyable for me. The main reason for this was the pretty actors ;) and the expectation that something special was going to happen like a sudden plottwist. To sum it all up I'd simply say that the movie wasn't terrible because enough money was put into it, but it was bad. This is a movie where I feel like there's a part missing. A part that I can't put my finger on. A part that got lost because the people responsible for making the film got lazy. If you want to watch this movie, please don't even think of good movies like the Matrix or Forrest Gump to compare it with for your own safety.

But apart from that, it's one of the worst I've seen in a long time. Cage has a tradition of starring in both good and and bad movies, this ranks at the bottom of the latter category. There's no point even trying to figure out what they were trying to do. It just goes from one bad cliche to another mixed with things that absolutely don't make sense. I suggest you watch this, just to torture yourself.

reviews.review_title: worst movie I have seen in years.
reviews.content: Wow. The worst movie I have seen in years. Horrible script, horrible acting. What an embarrassment for Nick Cage. This movie actually made me laugh at how campy and cheesy it was. This script reads like a draft version from a first year film student and you just wonder why they didn't do their homework on such an important endeavor. God bless Paul Lalonde for getting this made, but God can't turn a bad script into a good movie just because a producer deserves it and that's the lesson for everyone.Prayer is great, but God expects you to do the work and that includes having the right people at your side to support you.
