Okay, so I have watched the original one with Kirk Cameron, which I loved and own. I also have the other movies. So, when I saw this, I thought this couldn't be the same movie; they couldn't be remaking Left Behind. I was wrong. Seeing Nicholas Cage and Lea Thompson as the top named actors for this production, I thought it couldn't be that bad. It was. I'm not one to leave reviews and I'm not one to judge a movie based on reviews, but this one I had to. First, the acting was sub par. Cage movies, for me, are always a hit or miss. Sometimes he hits and does a wonderful job and sometimes he misses and it's awful. His character in this did not have any range. I wondered why he would do this movie to begin with, given it is supposed to be a Christian movie, but when I saw it, I can say that he didn't overact at all, but underacted. There was no passion, no connection with the character. It was flat when it should have been round. Second, the daughter. Her acting was way to over done. I couldn't help but wonder if she did this because she didn't know how to portray the character or if that was her interpretation of the character. Third, the script. I can't think of another movie off the top of my head where the main two characters are solely set in two scenes. There is so much more to this movie, book, than just two scenes. It took away from the whole meaning of what the book is about. There was no detail about the rapture, which by the way is the term used when all the people disappear and go to heaven. There was no in depth discussion of God or what was coming. The characters, like I said before and I know this has a lot to do with the writing, were flat, they didn't really grow. Instead they seemed to take the whole thing like it happened everyday and, well, they were wrong. The supporting characters on the plane also reacted in ways that were not believable. I know when it does happen people will be confused, upset, scared, etc, but they just didn't seem to really get it. Fourth, the movie lacked any spiritual message. This movie is about people being left behind to deal with the tribulation that will happen after the rapture. The anti-Christ coming, and the new world order. The message underlying this movie is supposed to be about being or getting saved so those who live by and for God, have a chance to be taken up during the rapture and not left behind. It's supposed to be spiritually moving and awaken that God shaped hole inside of us to seek Him out. It did not. It failed at the purpose behind the author writing it. It wasn't just for entertainment value, but to wake people up and bring them to God. My final thoughts on this movie as I sat and watched all of it, were why did they even make it? Were they just in a crunch and needed something to produce? It is regurgitated in a way that leaves anyone who has read the books or seen the original movie wanting something else. They should have just left it behind and found something else to produce.

A big-budget Left Behind remake film had all the chances of becoming a spectacular film that would be faithful to the original books written by Tim LaHaye and Jerry B. Jenkins. Instead, what we get is mostly just the first half of the first book expanded into an airline disaster film that is not entirely bad in its presentation, but not what I would go to see this in the theaters for. The rest of the first book's elements and characters are entirely left out, possibly for a sequel film but who knows, leaving us with a dumbed-down adaptation designed mostly to get people in the theater seats to watch it. The 2000 Cloud Ten Pictures version was much better at handling the entire story of the first book, compressed as it was for the amount of screen time the studio could afford to show it in. Let's hope and pray that this film succeeds at least enough to warrant a sequel where the Antichrist gets properly introduced and we get to see stuff going down as in the original books.

Thank God, Tim LaHaye and Jerry B Jenkins finished the books before these hacks got a hold of the idea.

reviews.content: Okay so this isn't the greatest movie ever but is a better remake of the 2000, Left Behind: The Movie.And its certainly not a rip-off of "The Leftovers", like one review seems to claim. reviews.review_title: This movie points fingers at everyone...
reviews.content: From the overly zealous know-it-all Christian to the jumpy person who prejudges people based on appearance, to the unfaithful husband...Everyone gets a cameo! In spite of some of the reviews, the movie doesn't show Christians in the best light, with people who are expected to be called away in the Rapture not even going. Some people who are expected to be "bad" in this movie, actually turn out to be good people.The rioting scenes are not significantly different from those in, say, "Independence Day," or any other apocalyptic movie.As far as reviews go, I find it hysterical when people go out of their way to vote down a movie they know, from the get-go, they won't like, especially when they spend money on them. lol. I have never watched "The Animal." Why? It's not my cup of tea. So, I didn't watch it, and because of that, I didn't rate it. I have watched movies I've hated, but I didn't go around telling everyone not to watch it. I give this movie 8/10, because yeah, some of the dialog stinks, some of the graphics are so-so, but it's got Nick Cage, explosions (lol), and doesn't let any archetype get away without some scrutiny.I won't even get into Biblical doctrine, which I know is a large point of contention with these books and movies, because this story is an interpretation only. I'm not sure we're meant to completely understand the Bible on this point.I hope the next one is even better! Better writing, better plot development, better graphics!

Here's a film with religious material, it means well, but you have to go into it remembering that:It's a Hollywood production It needs to appeal to everyone.Such is the case, the few Christians seen near the beginning are the typical Hollywood version (eg preachy, obnoxious) but then when the event happens in the film it's a bit of a slog as the passengers on the plane freak out, while on the ground things are also happening.Nicolas Cage is probably the only reason it's not a 1. The acting in the film isn't terrible (better than Asylum films) but it's rather stiff due to trying to appeal to a broad audience and not just a Christian audience. So there's a variety of people in the film at the beginning.So ultimately I believe it failed more with Christian audiences because of how they were portrayed. However it's difficult to appeal to a broad audience with Christian subject material, because such materials are often preaching-to-the-choir, and people don't like to be preached at, so the film avoids doing that. To appeal to a broad audience, the film toned down much of Christian symbolism, and left it to the audience interpret why the people were left behind.A different film, "This is the End" - which is a Seth Rogan film, though it's a comedy, I feel it was more on-the-nose about the subject material.I'd recommend showing "Left Behind" to film studies classes on adaption decay. How you can't dilute a film's controversial source material to gain a broad audience appeal, since it will always backfire.

I really wanted to like this movie. As an open minded Christian I thought it would be interesting to see how people envision their belief in the rapture. But this movie would be better off on Pureflix or something. It's pure prosthelytizing. They had a bunch of stereotypical "sinners" and non-believers. The philanderer, the gambler, the drug user, the person who puts money above all, the Muslim, etc. These are very one-dimensional characters and it showed. The acting was atrocious and the conversations did not seem natural but simply scripted prosthelytizing. There were many plot holes and ill-conceived concepts that despite trying to like this movie I couldn't. If I didn't watch it for "free" on prime I would ask for my money back like others. Wasted two hours of my life.On a side note I doubt even more now that the rapture is scruptural according to this envisioning of it. It makes it seem like God doesn't care about the world or its inhabitants. When they showed a dog on a chain with its owner gone I am like, no loving god would leave that poor dog to likely starve to death...

There are two different scenarios if you watch this film:If you are a Christian, you will see a cheesy action-drama that makes disappointing changes from the novel and a spiritual message weaker than Cage's performance.If you are anyone else, you will see an awkward action-drama that provides clichéd end-of-the-world footage along with a preachy, confusing explanation that interrupts the suspenseful moments.There are several points where you will have to really stretch your suspension of disbelief. The acting is marginal, Cage is predictably boring, but Buck was a good actor. The CGI is not the worst I've seen, but for 2014, it, along with the set production, definitely feels low budget. The movie's plot and main topic will make it difficult to find an audience, or a sequel.FX: 3/10 Characters: 5/10 Plot: 4/10Overall: 4/10 Consensus: If you really want to see this, or are a fan of Nicolas Cage's dull acting at its finest, wait until it comes on DVD. If you are part of a congregation, see if you can get a large group discount at the theater.

reviews.review_title: Quite shockingly bad - save your time!
reviews.content: There is nothing - NOTHING - to redeem this film. The script is simply awful and the acting doesn't even try to rescue it.If it's meant to promote Christianity, I'm pretty sure this has the opposite effect. It is in fact a deeply depressing view on a warped Christianity and it's saddening to think the screenplay writers could be so misinformed and capable of such gross generalisations. And it doesn't stop at Christianity either, there's the horrific slur, not just by implication, but directly, of the token Muslim on the plane, clearly badged as a potential terrorist and one of the 'bad' ones. There was a point when I though this might be a comedy after all, but nope, I quickly realised it was not funny (or clever) on any level. I've not even started to consider the multiple implausible scenes here - the other excellent reviews do a great job of that. This film should never have been made. The money could have gone to good causes. Or just another film.

reviews.review_title: This movie is so bad, it's actually a decent B movie (spoliers)
reviews.content: Yes, this movie is as dreadful as they come. The acting is so forced, you can feel everyone's souls dying a little more every scene. The dialogue reminds me of the anecdote that if you give a room full of monkeys each a typewriter eventually they'll spit out Shakespeare. For example, all the children and a good number of adults just up and vanished from a plane flying over the Atlantic, and all the stewardess can think of is how the captain lied to her about his wife. Because, priorities.The editing is mind boggling, towards the end every scene is at night, yet every outdoor shot is showing the sun coming up. I'm yelling at my screen "Will it ever be dawn again?!?!?!?" And I can't be the only one who noticed that when Chloe is standing on the bridge and the camera's panned out, it's a stunt double with curly hair. Could they not have afforded a hair straightener to at least pretend it's the same person? Probably the worst movie of the last decade, but everything about this production brought me back to Ed Wood. So horrible, an absolute train wreck of a film, but I couldn't stop laughing. And that my friends, is entertainment.

Many people discuss this movie too seriously with so many unnecessary sarcastic questions like why Christian believe in God. Or why do their body vanished. Or Do you believe that ?? .. and so on... Hey... there are hundreds or maybe thousands of nonsense stories movies ever made and some of them are even have more irrational stories...nobody really get irritated with them. So...those who believe in this image that the movie tries to tell...let it become your experience and reminder in a positive way...and those who doesn't believe it ...so be it...just enjoy it as another movie. It's unfair to judge the actors just because you don't believe the stories. It's like you judge Downey just because you don't believe Superhero is exist.

reviews.review_title: I'm a Christian but this movie was awful!
reviews.content: I'm a Christian, so this movie was geared towards people just like me. When I heard there was going to be doing a "big budget" movie of the Left Behind book, I was kind of excited. I was a fan of the books when they first came out. Saw the original with Kirk Cameron, and it was only so-so. So I was hoping for a really good movie. To say I was disappointed is an understatement. Ended up turning it off after only 20-30 minutes. The acting was awful. The writing/dialog was awful. It was 100 times worse than the Kirk Cameron version and honestly neither movies do justice to the books. Nicholas Cage's acting is awful, I don't know what happened to him over the years, but his acting has really gone downhill.Recently there have been a number of REALLY well done faith based movies. The production values and acting have begun to be closer to more mainstream movies. But this movie was a stinker.

Most of the shots are generic people walking around over generic places with nothing whatsoever to add to the movie. Then the script.. Looks like you have to be Christian to get into heaven because at least we get to know that the devout Muslim is definitely not on the list. The plot makes little sense as it tries to say that if us Christians leave earth, everything will fall apart...Anyway, when the movie does start there is nice acting and pace as it kind of hooks you to see what is going to happen. Btw, Nicholas Cage acting is VERY good through the whole movie. In the end the movie if cut right might have a much higher rating but as it stands i cannot recommend it to anyone.

A once great actor who's being manipulated late in his acting career. Why cast his over cooked face as a unsterile looking jet liner pilot for a pointless sleezy movie ride?

Does that mean that they are promoting drug use? Does it make you smart somehow? What about the dogs? God is so cruel that he leaves a Rottweiler behind? Did he at least take poodles? Strip away the religious aspect and you're left with a mash up of Flightplan, Non-Stop and Snakes on a Plane: three films which, in my humble opinion, all had fantastic elements of mystery, thrill and suspense. By the time I was seated to watch Left Behind stepping up to bat in the "some sort of aeroplane-based disaster" innings, I was expecting the appeal to have worn off somewhat.But oddly enough, it hadn't worn off all that much. Granted I wasn't exactly immersed: the opening wasn't so much tension-building as "so yeah, is something interesting gonna happen yet?". And of course the ending, which I won't spoil but regardless don't think actually can't be spoilt, is arguably anti-climatic in comparison to... well, anything.And yet, even as a non-religious viewer, I was not at all put off by the Christian theme - in the same way I can enjoy Harry Potter without believing in magic. Between disequilibrium and conclusion it was fairly well-directed, transitioning between characters at the right times, and reasonably realistic for the given scenario.There's not much else to fault. Aside from the acting skills (or lack thereof) of children, Cassi Thompson plays her role well, and you don't even need to give Nic Cage's character a name because he's just Nic Cage in everything these days - which is not necessarily a bad thing if you're a fan.Regardless of your beliefs, by factoring out religion entirely, Left Behind can actually be appreciated (just pretend it's like Harry Potter - anything's possible) and I wouldn't say it's as awful as everyone is making it out to be. A long shot from amazing, yes, but worth a one-time watch nonetheless, and if Cage signs on for the sequels, I'm down. It's not like National Treasure 3 is coming out any time soon.

I saw it and I'll be honest, it wasn't great but I don't think it was terrible either. Sure the acting could use some improvement but once after I saw this movie, I felt inspired to own up to a few things to people that I've greatly disputed with. The fact that the rapture will happen sometime in the future and terrible events to happen afterwords (not event specifically according to the movie) made me wonder if getting left behind would happen to me, that is if it would happen in my life time. The things that got me puzzled in this movie were a few people who were left behind when the rapture happened. 1) The lady with dementia or a dementia related illness. She was left behind but her husband was taken, that threw me off because I didn't think someone like deserved to be left behind due to the fact that they can't recognize the situation they were in. I didn't know if the person deserved whether or not to go to heaven but that's not my decision to make. 2) The dog that was left behind when his master was taken. It's like really? That was a heart breaking moment for me and I just couldn't believe that's what will happen when the rapture happens. 3) The Muslim. despite the fact I'm a Christian, I find it hard to believe that just Christian that will be saved. The bible talks a lot about envy for children and that God loves children but to be honest, it also talks a lot about how steeling and murder are very bad things for which many children in the world have done these things. reviews.review_title: Why Nick? Why did you take this role?
reviews.content: I like Nicolas Cage. I enjoy most of the movies he plays in, but this is definitely not one of them. Even he must've realized that at one point in production because his acting shifts monotonous in the airplane scenes. One would expect a Captain Steele (especially if played by Nick Cage) to be more heroic. If not, at least scared soiled-pants. Some kind more "reactive", or whatever. It seemed as if Steele's character barely made it as a secondary role. I was expecting a sci-fi movie, but was deceptively turned down with biblical connotations (I admit never having read the books, so couldn't know). When I figured that much partly through the movie (even before it was explained because this movie is so simple and predictive), I was expecting... no wait... I was HOPING to get something more out of it. And I waited. Waited. Wasted good popcorn while waiting. AND THEN IT CAME: the end credits. I was so disappointed.The story can be explained in two (more like one and a half) sentences: Millions of people disappeared in the blink of an eye while Capt. Steele is flying his plane and needs to emergency land (obviously); achieved with the help of his multi-talented super cute college daughter.Anything else to support the story-line is thinned out (stretched) to an almost meaningless state. There's character development where it isn't always necessary. Scenes seem to get repetitive. College girl can drive a motorcycle picked up on the street and a construction roller left on site (bet she could pilot a helicopter too, why not?). She blows things up. Finds the only place to enter a building unnoticed, while rioting people try to make their way inside in anyway possible.All in all, if my review can prevent some of you to watch this movie, then I will have saved two hours from each of you so you can watch something better that deserves popcorn. The only reason I rated this flick a 2 is because Nicolas Cage's name is on the cover and Cassi Thomson is cute.
Poor acting combined with pathetic special effects. Plot also failed. Nick - catch yourself on.

I don't know why all the hatred towards this film just because it mentions a quote from the Bible. Are we so anti-religious ? This is not a religious film. There is just the fact that millions have disappeared in thin air (apparently gone to heaven) while a whole lot of chaos is left behind. I've enjoyed the 70's and 80's Airport movies and this film has a sort of feel of such movies as the tension is there although I must admit that there are movies out there with similar plane sequences which I never fail to get fed up of seeing.

reviews.review_title: The original good vs evil doomsday plot, as one interpretation of Revelations
reviews.content: We need more movies like this. I will support this movie so Hollywood can see there is a interest in these type of movies. Good vs Evil, end times, doomsday; these are all the things that make movies like '2012' blockbusters. This movie doesn't deliver on the wow factor with acting and set-up but it doesn't ruin the movie either. Plus, this is the first movie in a planned series. Like the LOTR trilogy, I don't expect much in the first installment except build-up. Revelations is the best and most interesting doomsday plot. reviews.review_title: No Christian Agenda despite earlier posts
reviews.content: Having previously read the book series, I was happy to see a much more polished production, and better actors than the 2000 version. When you cast Kirk Cameron and he's the star talent, well....... I disagree that there was hidden Christian agendas throughout the movie. The whole book series is closely based on the book of Revelations as the events unfold. The only real creative liberties taken were in the creation of characters to give the story a human element. The actual series is quite long, and if they develop the book series to the big screen, I think you'll find that it's not portraying the ones Left Behind as moral degenerates but, more like regular people drowning in the culture of greed that the world is becoming. I say this because, later in the series these folks become the heroes, again creating the human element, as you witness them develop into their full potential. Sure, the story comes from the Christian bible but, the human element is quite real and exists in each of us. Who doesn't know someone that's been flattened by the churning machine our world has become and never really completely recover? Just follow the series and you'll see that it's all about the unique qualities, skills and gifts that reside in ALL of us, and the elements of self reflection and realization. Many can argue (and I'll usually agree) that the modern Christian church message is pretty distorted, and pretty judgmental. But, few can argue that the actual message of Christ (whether you are a believer or not) is a beautiful message teaching tolerance, patience, compassion and love toward each other, regardless of how they believe, social status, income bracket, etc. You could almost say He created the first MASS hippie movement of that time. Teaching peace, love and tolerance. :)

When I heard they made a new Left Behind, I groaned. But after watching this amazing movie I really appreciated what they did with it. As for Martin Klebba's character I can relate to most. Not willing to jump on any band wagon but not totally dismissing it either. Not every movie out there is the type I can watch with my parents or grand parents. But Left Behind is family friendly and has a fantastic cast. I really hope that Mr. Cage will continue his fantastic work as Rayford Steele and have many more movies with this level of excitement.

reviews.review_title: Not nearly as bad as the reviews here let to be believe IMHO

She wanted to watch it, I was like uhh.... Well came to IMDb to see rating and some reviews. Seeing the very low rating and multiple reviews with 1 star and quite heavy bashing I was expecting a real bad movie and sort of just wanted to see how bad it is. But it wasn't that bad at all. Many wrote this is the worst film they've seen, but personally I've seen a LOT of films LOT worse than this. To give it 1 star is a joke IMO. At the end of the movie they say "it looks like the end of the world", "no, it's just beginning", I was like alright, bring it on! It could have easily been alien ships in the end seen on over the city if we didn't knew before hand what the movie was about (there's really not that much religious stuff at all in the movie, the characters actually have multiple and even some funny theories about what's going on). Take from it that it drags on at some parts and you have the attention span of a flea. Or take from it the possible points where civilization is leading itself. Being suspicious and mean purely because they can.Being Christian isn't about black and white, there are some rules that are constant, and there are some things we just have to take on faith that in /some/ way, whether it's literally or figuratively things will happen. Some people will see it as a rotational cleansing of the world by the world or cosmos itself. Others will see it as a godly action. It's not the point though. The important part is where you'll be if something happens. Will you be someone making it worse or someone trying to help people through. Being Christian is about loving people and being there for them. If you're a thumper, good for you, your faith is strong and I hope it's the way you think it should be. For those who don't believe, the universe is cyclical, look through history. SOmething will happen someday, when and what who knows. For everyone else, sometimes the story isn't something as a whole that's taken but small parts that are the most relevant to you.

reviews.review_title: Terrible book-to-movie, terrible Christian movie, terrible movie.
reviews.content: Ever since I heard that "Left Behind" was being rebooted and that Nicolas Cage was starring in it, I hoped that it was one big April Fool's joke. It wasn't.The first two "Left Behind" books were made into three movies from 2000-2005 by Cloud Ten Productions. They were terrible (but not as terrible as the new one). They were so terrible that book series co- author Tim LaHaye sued to get the movie rights back. After a lengthy court battle, he won in 2008. Unfortunately, the deal said that he had a few years to make his own movie and he was not able to, so the original producers got the movie rights back. So they decided to make another "Left Behind" movie, a reboot that made "The Amazing Spider-Man" look like a good idea.The "Left Behind" movies Cloud Ten previously made starred teen heart-throb turned evangelist Kirk Cameron. Other movies made by the company have starred Gary Busey and Mr. T. But with the new "Left Behind" movie, they decided they were ready for the big league and nabbed Nicolas Cage - the actor who never turns down a role. (Actually, he dropped out of "Expendables 3" in order to star in "Left Behind".)As a big fan of the books, I felt like I was being pranked as every new detail came out about the new movie. When production didn't start as scheduled in spring 2013, I hoped that it wouldn't be made. Filming was pushed to late summer. When it got to be one month before the scheduled June 20, 2014 release and there still wasn't a trailer, I hoped that the movie wouldn't be released. The release was rescheduled for October.I looked forward to the movie as much as the average "Star Wars" fan would look forward to George Lucas writing and directing a JarJar Binks movie (which would be a better movie than the new "Left Behind" movie). I started watching it knowing that it was going to be horrible. It was worse. I can't even mention everything that movie made me feel. Just know that as bad as it was for you to watch it, it was an even worse for a fan of the books.To quote one movie review, "Cloud Ten was sued for making a bad Left Behind movie. The newest rendition of Left Behind is not just bad. It's act of vengeance on Tim LaHaye for the years of courtroom battles." And now he and co-author Jerry Jenkins are forced to break the ninth commandment and say that the movie is really good and that they enjoyed it.And so I am, and probably everybody who watched the new "Left Behind" movie are, waiting for an apology from producer Paul Lalonde. Expect another bad movie before the apology comes. Or maybe even the Rapture.

Make a horrible movie that happens to be about religion you get this type of reaction.Because not only atheist who hate just about everything religion related will despise the movie,but you have people of other beliefs disgusted at yet again another medium with false or alternate teachings a la The Rapture and you have the average movie buff that just hates horrible movies.Overall this movie was just a horribly executed.I actually chuckled when the boy disappeared because of how obvious the timing of the event was.The movie would have taken a good turn if the mother didn't get "raptured" for her false teachings.I'm not a religious guy but I do have my faith.So I give the movie, that I just rented from netflix a 3/10. reviews.review_title: Great Movie with poor special effects
reviews.content: Considering the Rating of 3.1 in the Data Base I was expecting a complete disappointment but surprisingly the movie kept me in suspense till the last moment and had great twists and turns. Regarding the plot it's extremely difficult to predict anything in the film.Obviously I didn't know what to expect. After a slow start the movie takes you on a ride and holds your attention till the end. Probably the movie was rated bad due to it's low budget which is making itself present in the poor special effects. The movie is probably also not what you would expect of a Nicolas Cage movie as it lacks the usual amount of sex and violence (obviously another reason for it's bad rating). What counts for me is the unpredictability and the suspense, but most of all, what blows your mind is the mystery. If you like mystery and suspense you will enjoy this film.I'm giving it a 7 because of the poor special effects. But the special effects are not what counts in this film and even without them it would still be a great movie. Out of the Rapture topic of films out there, this one is perhaps the better one regarding the biblical topic of what may happen when Yeshua (aka Jesus the Jewish Messiah) calls out and takes out all the believers and followers on Earth. I like how a bit of humor was woven into the storyline.

What I liked is there is plenty of action and it deals head-on with the essence of belief and takes on a plot idea that is rarely or never approached. Nicholas Cage as usual is totally and enthusiastically committed in the role. Gotta say - other reviews I have seen are tough - seem to mix up their own views on Christianity with a movie about Christianity.

I'm very surprised that I actually liked it. Given the subject matter, I was worried it was either going to be too pro-religion with lots of "preaching" or too anti-religion and just a hate fest against religious folks. But instead the movie focused on the characters and how they dealt with the immediate dangers that they faced. There's not much of an arc for anyone as it's played mostly as an action movie. It felt like they might've been setting up for a sequel where some of the characters would find some sort of meaningful change, but sadly that doesn't happen here and there's no sequel I can find. But I did think it was an enjoyable and entertaining way to pass the time. Nicholas Cage is great as usual, Cassi Thomson was very good and believable as his daughter, and I was really surprised at how good Nicky Whelan was as the flight attendant that Nic Cage's character is having an affair with. That character could easily have been a typical clichéd "evil other woman" and "flight attendant from hell" who hates her passengers. But Whelan (and the writers) make her very real and interesting. There's some unnecessary, and thankfully brief, subplots on the plane, but overall I found it a pleasant surprise.

rt_summary: The entire planet is thrown into mayhem when millions of people disappear without a trace -- all that remains are their clothes and belongings. Unmanned vehicles crash and planes fall from the sky, overwhelming emergency forces and causing massive gridlock, riots and chaos. Airline pilot Ray Steele (Nicolas Cage) struggles to save the lives of the passengers who remain on his flight, while his daughter (Cassi Thomson) races to find her brother and mother, both of whom have disappeared.
